text: OPEN ON MARTIN HART staring directly at us, seated at a TABLE. He’s 56, tall, broad. He has thick gray hair, clos cropped, a hard face. He wears a well-made suit, and ther a kind of physical intensity in his bearing. He simmers-- Cigarette burns and gouges pock the table’s linoleum surf and behind Hart is only a green plaster WALL, empty excep for its upper right side, in which half a BULLETIN BOARD in frame, and on it, half of a WANTED POSTER can be seen- As Martin stares at us, WORDS are typed into the bottom o the screen, courier typeface, to the SOUND of keys punchi CHYRON: ‘Arkansas State Police CID, Company D / Statement Hart, Martin Eric. / Present: Sgt. Thomas F. Papania, Sgt Maynard Gilbough / May, 2010’

(into camera) What’d I think? ...You know they called him ‘The Banker’ for a while?.. Department opened up some new positions in CID that year. Cocaine was on the rise, and meth was getting big. So I partnered up. A beat, then he seems to speak as if in response to a question-- HART (CONT’D) Seemed a little raw-boned to me. A little edgy. Finally get him over for dinner, around the time of our first female 419- the ‘Pine Angel’ in Benton County... That’s what you all really want to talk about, right? Dora Lange? Another beat as he seems to listen--  HART (CONT’D) Alright. Rust- Well, as a ‘for instance,’ I finally got him over for dinner. The case was still hot, and I had a bit of respect for him by then, seeing how he ran out front with it. So one evening, a Tuesday maybe-? INT. HART HOME - NIGHT (CHYRON- typed: ‘1990’) MARTIN HART, 36, in better shape and with darker hair, answers his front door. It opens onto RUSTIN COHLE, 31, smaller, handsome but hard-worn, his shirt and suit disheveled. Bleary-eyed and frightened, he stands on the porch with a cheap BOUQUET in hand, as the 2010 Hart spea
Poor bastard looked like he was on his way to a firing squad. Then I see it- His dark hair mussed, Rust shakily holds out the bouquet. CLOSE ON his face- wet, red eyes, red nose-
He’s blind drunk.

Bring him in, Marty! Let’s get a look at him! PULL BACK onto the house and see that it is the modest, w maintained home of a middle-class family with small child Hart and Cohle look back and forth at one another, Cohle’ look apologetic and helpless, both understanding that he’ no shape to have dinner with Hart’s family. Hart puts a h on his shoulder, takes the flowers and leads Cohle in-

Just smile and you’1l be fine. I’11 put coffee on. We’ll get somebody to call up here with an excuse for you to leave. Cohle looks like he might cry, either from gratitude or terror-- Then TWO LITTLE GIRLS come hopping in- AUDREY, 10, and MA 7. They surround the two men, giddy at the new visitor. F moment, these two stern men look absolutely baffled by th little girls jumping at their calves, the wilted flowers hanging between them-

The same interrogation room, but the chair is EMPTY. A NE MAN steps into frame, sits down. Recognize RUSTIN COHLE, twenty years older, taking Hart’s place across the table, staring at us. Same wall with a corner of the BULLETIN BO behind him, same piece of a WANTED POSTER-- He hasn’t lost any hair, but it’s streaked with steel gra wild, unkempt and in need of a trim. He’s leaner. In the intervening years he’s shed pounds, and now his cheeks ar sunken. He almost looks emaciated, lupine. He’s unshaven, wearing rumpled clothes. NOTICE covering Cohle’s left inn forearm, a colorful, slightly-faded TATTOO of FLAMES with PAIR OF DICE at their apex-- CHYRON (typed): ‘Arkansas State Police CID / Company D / Statement of Cohle, Rustin Spencer. / Present: Sgt. Thoma Papania, Sgt. Maynard Gilbough / May, 2010’ Cohle clears his throat, his voice gravelly, when he fina speaks it’s as if in answer to a question-

(into camera) Yeah. Of course. ‘The Pine Angel.’ Thank the Democrat-Gazette for that one. Cohle pauses and lights a CIGARETTE. Then suddenly looks between it and the camera, as though he’s being admonishe He deliberates the lit cigarette. Then keeps smoking- COHLE (CONT’D) Don’t be a dick about it... You want to hear this or not? (smokes ) Benton County Sheriff requested assistance with a 419 at the edge of the woods off Highway 20. South of Eureka Springs. This our first real heater. I’d been around about three months at the time. Had just observed Marty, till then. Cohle ashes on the table, staring belligerently -

Red clouds and a red sunrise. A heavily wooded VALLEY surrounded with denser FOREST, the OZARKS fencing the hor in dun-colored spikes. Blobs of GRAY SNOW litter the dark soil. A crisp, ruby light--  4. FOLLOWING THREE MEN across this valley: a uniformed SHERI DEPUTY walking point, leading TWO MEN IN TRENCHCOATS and suits, MARTIN HART and RUSTIN COHLE, c.1990. Hart’s hands stuffed in his pockets, and Cohle carries a CRIME SCENE K and a LEGAL-SIZED PORTFOLIO-- We watch the deputy leading them toward deeper woods. NOT all the birds roosting outside the forest, and 2010 Cohle speaks in V.O.--

Last gasp of winter. It was about seven a.m., March 3, 1990. My daughter's birthday, I remember. Walking, Rustin sees a BLACK SNAKE winding through the gr away from the direction they’re traveling-- ANGLE AHEAD- where the TREE LINE breaks. SHERIFF'S DEPUTI stand a couple dozen yards from a DARK SHAPE hunched at t base of a LARGE PINE TREE. The men talk between themselve their backs turned away from the shape, breath visible in crisp air--

Without saying anything, the deputy leads Hart and Cohle the dark, slumped shape. The deputy tries not to look at but can’t help himself-- ON HART and COHLE’S FACES as the deputy steps aside. Hart looks vaguely horrified. Cohle’s face simply tenses and h eyes sharpen. Behind them, birds shriek from the trees-- Cohle moves past Hart to get closer-- ANGLE ON BODY- (depicted as mercifully as possible) -A wh FEMALE, naked, posed kneeling over a LARGE TREE ROOT, her HANDS folded as if in prayer. Head down, a CROWN of ROOTS THORNS is set on her scalp. A PAIR OF LARGE, DARK WINGS h been attached to her back. The WINGS drape over her ribs, their feather-tips sunken into a small patch of dirty sno Cohle puts on a pair of latex gloves and looks from the b to the TREES around it- NOTICE a PENTAGRAM freshly carved into the pine tree beside the body--

Holy God. Cohle crouches to examine the WINGS. ANGLE ON his hands shifting the feathers.  5. NOTICE the wings are bonded at their axillars with some k of industrial adhesive which has scoured the flesh around them with CHEMICAL BURNS. Cohle gently grasps her head an lifts her FACE- Her face is intact, her eyes gray and dull. It’s not an unattractive face, but white, and something subtle in it- parting of the lips -almost suggests a rapture--
(to deputies) You guys touch anything? One of the uniformed men steps out. SHERIFF TATE, 49, sof and booze-reddened-
They know all about crime scenes. You think anybody wants to touch this?
Who found her?
Hospital chopper on its way to St. Jude's spotted her. Phoned us.
(stands)
County’s on his way. Wade Davis. Good man. Cohle looks back at the body, the crown, the wings-

Bullshit. Call state’s. Tell them to send Gordon DiCillo. Tate flares his nostrils, shares a pissed-off glance with deputies. Marty sighs- this rude android for a partner-- Again crouching, Cohle examines the body. FOLLOW his hand which move gently in feathery touches and grips, disturbi as little as possible, while his V.O. speaks-
It was pretty fresh. Animals hadn't been at it. She still had her eyes.  He moves his hands down her body, noting bruises-

Lividity at her shoulders, thighs and anterior torso. She was on her stomach a while before he moved her here. ANGLE ON a BLACK MINI-SKIRT hanging above the body on branches, the skirt cut down the middle and spread open l a bat’s wings--
You ever seen anything like this?
No. Eleven years CID.

Satanic. That’s the word for it. They had a 20/20 on it last year. The SUN has risen higher, and now a SUNBEAM has come down lighting the tableau as if by spotlight. ALL the men noti Cohle looks up, and sees that the killer positioned the b directly beneath a break in the trees, so that sun would purposefully light her figure-
She looks like some kind of religious statue. Cohle looks at her in the sunbeam with new eyes, halted a seeing things differently-

Tate shakes his head. Cohle looks toward the shadows of t Ozarks, the low valley between them a desolate flatness. turns to Hart- a glance gives Cohle permission to take le COHLE (CONT’D) (to Sheriff's) We need more men for a grid search. We'll get troopers out here, but we could use more deputies. I need you guys to set up a perimeter- He points back through the fields, at the far convergence rural highways-  COHLE (CONT’D) -wide as possible on those three roads. One of you post up. Take license plates of anything that passes, too. The deputies just stare at Cohle until he eyes Sheriff Ta Sheriff Tate nods to his men, and they disperse to take positions. Hart pulls out a LARGE RADIO from his trenchco
A23. We need trooper assist on that 419. All you can spare for canvass.

Roger, A23. When he’s done, he puts on latex gloves and crouches besi Cohle, who's already kneeling beside the body. Notice Coh doesn’t care about his pant knees as he writes on that bi LEGAL PAD he’s brought-
(writing) Ligature marks at wrists and ankles. Hemorrhaging around the throat.
The 2010 frame, and 56-year old Martin Hart-

(into camera) That's why they called him ‘The Banker’. Most of us, you know, used a little notepad you’d have ina pocket. Rust carried this big portfolio. Wrote down everything. And his first couple months, he had to do a lot of canvassing. So it looked funny. Him going door to door with that big ledger, like the census taker. Thus, The Banker. Not so bad, far as nick-names go. As Martin speaks toward the camera, there is a withheld affection in his remembrance. Clearly, he has a complexit feelings about Rustin Cohle, but ‘respect’ is part of tha HART (CONT’D) I mean, I’d seen the different types. We all fit categories. The bully. The charmer. (MORE )

HART (CONT’D) The father-figure. The man possessed by ungovernable rage. The eyes. The brain... And any of those types can be a good detective. And any of those types can be an incompetent shitheel. It’s how they manage the burden of authority, yeah? He thinks a moment, perhaps listens to a comment from his interviewer-- HART (CONT’D) It’s like a father’s authority. A father’s burden. It’s too much for some people... Same thing I look for when I hire guys for the agency now. You want a certain toughness. But the kind that doesn’t veer toward callous. Because that’s a dangerous road. Aggression is necessary. It is. So’s compassion, a sense of fairness-
CRIME SCENE- Cohle and Hart continue examining the body, Cohle taking furious notes. We cannot hear what they say, only Hart’s 2010 testimony--
You want them to be thorough. To have good eyes, ask the right questions. To have steady habits. ON Cohle’s face as he studies the body, takes notes--

A smart guy who’s steady is hard to find. I mean, I admit, I wasn’t the most brilliant case man the division ever saw. I got lucky a few times. I was alright. Better than some. But I knew how to talk to people. And I was steady. Cohle writes furiously, scans the environment around the
Rust was smart.  EXT. ‘RAINBOW APARTMENTS’, NORTHWEST ARKANSAS - DAY A seedy BRICK line of APARTMENTS the size of motel rooms, the middle of nowhere- fields and desolation around.

Second week we were together I saw where he was living, and I felt for the guy. ANGLE ON an UNMARKED CID CAR, as Cohle and Hart step out, Hart follows his partner to a door-- INT. COHLE’S APARTMENT - DAY Cohle opens the door, and from Hart’s POV, we take in the ROOM. It’s empty except for a couple BOXES. Depressingly bleak and completely unadorned. A MATTRESS on the floor. CRUCIFIX above the mattress. No TV. STACKS OF THICK BOOKS various spots on the floor-

I thought of some Quasimodo character living in a belfry, like. He had these textbooks stacked on the floor-- ANGLE ON the BOOKS. NOTICE the TITLES: Advanced Crime Sce Analysis. Offender Profiling. Sex Crime Investigation. Advanced Homicide Investigation--
Hart looks at Cohle, a little weirded-out-
I’d offer you a seat.
Don’t mention it.
Martin Hart, 56-

You know the photos in those books. Not the sort of thing you’d leave lying around, at least if you expected anybody else to ever walk in your place... One of those moments I was glad I’d made a family.  10.

CRIME SCENE- Detectives Cohle and Hart are alone beside t body, having finished their examination. Cohle sits on a and continues writing on his tablet, looking around. Hart stands and talks on the radio. We can’t hear his 1988 voi only the 2010-

I didn’t really mind he was quiet. Mainly nobody understood what he was doing here. Brought in from Louisiana, and he wasn’t interested in making buddies. Hart puts down the radio, moves to where Cohle sits writi The body nearby, like a dark angel on the periphery of th frame- HART. DiCillo said he’1ll be here in twenty. Cohle doesn’t respond, keeps writing. Hart takes out a ca smokeless tobacco and fills his bottom lip. Then they bot wait, with the silence between them-- ANGLE ON Cohle’s tablet- he’s moved to drawing sketches o the crime scene and body-
Bobby and Steve and the other guys thought he was stuck up, like he thought he’s better than other people. But up close it was more complicated. More like a paranoia.
COHLE directs one section of the grid search, and MARTY another-- ON COHLE as he gives orders--
We didn’t know what he’d been doing. Before CID... I didn’t know about all that undercover work until later. A tinge of sympathy is evident in Hart’s voice--  11.
Rustin Cohle, age 51, disheveled, smoking. Somebody broug him an old coffee MUG to use as an ashtray- He pauses,

Yeah, well. Devil’s in the details, yeah? I wrote everything I could. Try to capture the moment, its essence. Because you never know what the thing’s going to be, do you? The essential, unlikely clue. Thing that, way down the line, maybe months or years later, makes you say, ‘Ah.’ Breaks the case wide. remembering, smokes-- COHLE (CONT’D) So we're sitting there waiting on Dicillo. This scene. I mean, we'd encountered a full-fledged meta- psychotic. I had to explain to Marty what that was-
CRIME SCENE: In the distance we can see DEPUTIES spreadin out across the fields. The detectives are still the only near the body. Cohle gestures to it as he speaks to Hart, portfolio laid down-
This is going to happen again.
What do you think you know?
This is fantasy enactment. There’s fetishization, something like... iconography.
Satanist shit.
No. But it’s a religious vision. Her body is a paraphilic lovemap.
A what?  12. Cohle’s eyes trawl over the body--
An attachment of physical lust to fantasies and practices forbidden by society.
You learn that in your books?
I did. You see how short that skirt was? Decent odds she’s a prost. Maybe a hitchhiker. But the guy’s been thinking about this a long time.
Just don’t want us jumping to any conclusions.
I bet we get ID off her prints. Hart, as senior detective, probes Cohle to test his judgm
What else?

Missing persons, obviously. We need to look into any reports of unrelated sexual events, like flashing or fetish burglaries. Check all prior arrests going back the last several years for the northwest counties. Any B&E with a fetish component. Sexual offenders paroled to the state. Hart is impressed by the rookie detective’s assessment. COHLE (CONT’D) These things don’t occur in a vacuum. Hart nods, and Cohle returns to sitting on his log, watch the body. Hart watches him-- Silence for several beats- this dark assemblage flirts wi absurdity- the two suited men sitting near that horrible corpse, being quiet like schoolboys or nervous suitors-- Hart seems perturbed, finally speaks-  13.
This is a stupid time to mention it. But you have to come over to the house for dinner. I can’t put Maggie off any more, and it’s shitty and rude for you not to. Cohle thinks--
Alright. Cohle looks slightly on edge now, grips his portfolio on lap, stares at the girl. STAY ON Cohle’s face, a dull dre in it, his eyes looking trapped as he sits with Hart--

I get this stone in my gut, see, because I think about Marty’s wife and his two girls, sitting down to dinner with this family, and I’m thinking about Sofia, my daughter, and how it’s her birthday. And how she’s been gone almost five years...
Older, haunted, Cohle continues his story--
And I know right then that I’m going to have a drink.

CRIME SCENE: Later. M.E. GORDON DICILLO has arrived, mid- 40s/50s. He squats by the BODY while an ASSISTANT takes photos under his direction-- In the FIELDS beyond, NOTICE STATE PATROLMEN and SHERIFF’ DEPUTIES walking a slow grid formation through the fields while a few other DEPUTIES hold off a PRESS VAN on the co road. COHLE and HART stand near DiCillo, Cohle almost loo over his shoulder-- ANGLE ON PRUNING SHEARS- DiCillo uses them to cut the WIN at their base with a wet, crunching sound--
Bagging these separate.  14.
See if you can find out what type of bird those belong to.
Looks like maybe a turkey vulture. A TROOPER approaches the detectives-
Sir? We got drag marks-
ANGLE ON slight STREAKS OF BLOOD on the HIGH GRASS, almos imperceptible, as is the wave of mashed-down GRASS leadin between the forest and the road-- Cohle studies them, looks to the road--
There's going to be some tire tracks on the shoulder of the road there. Can you make tread casts?
Yes, sir.

Alright. Get casts. Check the opposite shoulder. Cast anything over there, too. I got mold kits in my bag at the scene, if you need them. The trooper nods, hustles off, and Cohle looks at the dra trail, the dark trees and cold, bright sky. He sees SHERI TATE talking to NEWS REPORTERS by TWO NEWS VANS on the ro Cohle’s face scowls--
Cohle whistles with two fingers, waves the sheriff over. sheriff takes his time--
We need as much of this bend sealed off as possible. Tell the journalists they’re violating the scene.
They're in the road.  15.
Get them out. You realize what we just caught here?
Realize it’s my jurisdiction.

It was. But then you called us. I don’t know how they got here so quick, ‘less you called em, feeling left out. But get those jackasses gone. They’re parked on evidence. Tate’s face goes red. A staring contest, and he sees bad things in Cohle’s. The sheriff returns to the reporters-
HOURS LATER. Toward evening, Cohle and Hart drive in thei UNMARKED CID SEDAN, Hart behind the wheel. They pass VACA
Cohle goes through a stack of CANVASS REPORTS and FIELD STATEMENT FORMS on his lap, all filled with Cohle’s meticulous script-- the day’s work--
(re field reports) That’s six hours wasted.
Just that there’s not much around here.
These people out here. Like they got no idea the outside world exists. They might as well live on the moon.
You called her in to Missing Persons?
Yeah. First thing. See what DiCillo says, wait for I.D.?
I want to start a board. Cohle nods. Silence awhile, and Hart glances to him-  16. HART (CONT’D) Ask you something. That pentagram up there and stuff... You’re Christian, yeah?
What? Not on your life. This confuses Hart--
Saw that crucifix in your apartment...
Oh. That’s more like meditation. Hart is knee-jerk offended at Cohle’s nonchalance about T Son of Man--
How’s that?
I like to contemplate Christ’s life. As an existential statement. The idea of allowing your own crucifixion.
But you don’t believe He’s the Lord and Savior?
Not at all.
(appalled) What do you believe? Cohle glances at Hart with a tired expression, doesn’t answer. It’s clear he doesn’t want to, but Hart keeps loo at him in expectation--
You don’t want to know.
Three months. I get nothing out of you. And today? After what we're into now? Do me the simple courtesy of answering the question. I’m not trying to convert you.  17. Cohle sighs--
.-.-In philosophical terms, I’m what’s called a pessimist.
‘In philosophical terms,’ what’s that mean?

Means I’m bad at parties. Hart scowls at Cohle, prodding him on. Cohle continues, reluctant- COHLE (CONT’D) I think that human consciousness is a tragic evolutionary misstep. I think that nature fabricated an aspect of nature that’s forever separated from it. A creature that by natural law should not exist. Outside, the car passes a cheap, OLD BILLBOARD with a WOM PORTRAIT on it and the legend ‘10/11/80: DO YOU KNOW WHO KILLED ME? CALL 800-976-5236 REWARD’ -- COHLE (CONT’D) ...I think we are things that labor under the illusion of having a ‘self’, each of us programmed with total assurance that we’re each a somebody. But everybody’s nobody. Cohle gets on a roll now-- COHLE (CONT’D) See, we fabricate meaning in order to deny what we are, so that we can keep on going. Family, god, country, art- these are the materials of our fabrications. We’re uncanny puppets on a lonely planet, in cold space, living and replicating and sending unborn generations into suffering and death because that’s our programming. Hart’s eyes have gone wide with disbelief and frustration
Jesus Christ.  18.

No thanks. And Cohle’s a little enervated, as if, you asked for it-- COHLE (CONT’D) What I think? The only honorable thing for our species to do is deny our programming, stop reproducing and march hand-in-hand into extinction. A beat where Cohle seems almost wistful-- COHLE (CONT’D) A last sunset. Cosmic midnight. Hart’s deeply offended, angry-
So what's the point of life, huh?
There is no point. Nowhere to go, no one to see, nothing to do, nothing to be.
(enraged) Jesus Christ, Jesus Christ. You bleeding asshole. Most you've said in three months and it’s gotta be- what’s the matter with -Why’re you on the job, anyway?

The only real answer is that it’s obviously my programming. Just like it’s yours. He looks out the window as he speaks, almost to himself-- COHLE (CONT’D) The reason I tell myself? I’ma human being. I speak for the dead. I bear witness. It keeps me part of things. But mostly I lack the courage for suicide... Look, if you want, I could lend you some Schopenhauer. Start there.

Stop. Stop talking. Shit. Shit.  19. Back to silence. As Hart grinds his teeth, Cohle stares o the windows at the ISOLATED FIELDS and RAMSHACKLE HOMES, ELECTRICAL LINES against the DESOLATE VALLEY, BROKEN FENC several tense beats--

I get poor vibrations from this place. You can feel the psycho- field in the air. Like aluminum on your teeth. Hart doesn’t reply, drives on, disturbed, hoping Cohle wo talk anymore-- COHLE (CONT’D) Should I bring anything, for dinner? Horrified to be reminded of the dinner invitation, Hart r composes himself--
Bottle of wine, be nice. I guess.
I don’t really drink. This a final straw of disappointment for Hart--
Of course you don’t, Rust... And listen, at my house? Don’t mention any of that shit you just said to me. You asshole... ‘Extinction.’
Of course not, Marty. I’m not some maniac. Fuck’s sake. They drive in silence the rest of the way, as Hart’s 2010 vV.O. resumes and the CAR passes down the road, into the hills-

I mean, most of us are pretty hard right, you know? Christians. Good Republicans. We had pictures of Reagan, Bush and Nixon in the CID squad room. And at this point, no lie-- The CAR shrinks into the dark FOOTHILLS that bound the country road, vanishing into a red darkness--  20.
-I just really, really don’t like the guy.

location: ARKANSAS STATE POLICE HQ, FORT SMITH

text: ESTABLISHING the state police headquarters in Fort Smith. four-story administrative building with FLAGS out front, of PATROL and UNMARKED CARS, all late-80s TAURUSES. Hart Cohle’s pulls into the lot as the afternoon reddens towar sunset--

location: ARKANSAS STATE POLICE HQ, FORT SMITH

text: CID is located on the third floor, and Cohle and Hart ent The division is a large, open floor with CUBICLES, TYPEWRITERS, a RECEPTIONIST, and a FEW PLAINCLOTHES DETECTIVES at their desks, using the phones. A FLAG, slog posters, no computers. The receptionist flags Cohle-

Lieutenant wants you both. Soon as you got back, he told me. Cohle glances at Hart, who shrugs, walks away from him. H is quickly mobbed by the DETECTIVES in the room, all of w want to know about the red-ball he and Cohle have caught- Snatches of their conversation: ‘Said she had wings?’ ‘-t Heavy Metal music-’ ‘You need extra hands?’ ‘A 20/20 spec Etc. INT. LT. QUESADA’S OFFICE, CID - LATE AFTERNOON A boss's OFFICE. Cohle and Hart are sitting in two chairs that face the DESK and, behind it, LT. KEN QUESADA, 3rd S Homicide Commander, Company D, late 40s, chubby, wears a Knights of Columbus RING he likes to rub--
Mid-twenties to late-forties. Looks like strangulation. She had- I mean, you never even heard of anything like this--
She had wings attached to her back.
What, like a costume?
Like a real bird’s wings. Big wings, soldered onto her skin.  21.
Jesus.
This is the real thing, Loo. This is way out there.

That explains why the AP woman asked me about birds. And Satan worship. Godamnit. I had to yell in the sheriff's ear how it’s not a good idea to spout hysterical bullshit to local news. I chewed him up, but I might have to do a press conference tomorrow. Right now, keep it close. Get with me on DiCillo’s report. I’m first to know when you got an ID.
I’s going to get a board going.

You got anything for it? Hart shakes his head. QUESADA (CONT’D) Do it anyway. Incident room’s yours. Lead a briefing tomorrow. Tate wanted to liaise a couple men to us. We might need them, I guess. Scene gonna stay secured?
What good it’1l do. Supposed to snow tonight. A KNOCK on the office window: a SUIT stands there, and Quesada nods to him. Cohle and Hart rise, but--

Rust- stay here a minute, huh? Cohle and Hart share a glance as Hart exits, and the SUIT enters. This is Assistant State Attorney LEN SALTER, 40, carries a briefcase and closes the door behind him. Sits in Hart's vacant chair-- Cohle looks back and forth at the two men, who study him openly. As they speak, they are each obviously probing an gauging his reactions--  22. QUESADA (CONT’D) Rustin Cohle. Detective. Eight years with Baton Rouge PD. Four of those with the State Police Intra- agency Task Force... Front lines in the war on drugs.
Hard chargers. Took down some major busts. They called you ‘Crash’, right?
I heard that, too. ‘Crash’ Cohle.
They call you that because you bust things up?
It was a joke with the ITTF. Short for Crash Test Dummy.

Hear now they call you ‘The Banker.’ A beat as the two bosses examine Cohle, whose eyes have g hard, flinty-- SALTER (CONT’D) Your op details are redacted. Four years of duty sealed on the Louisiana AG’s orders or classified with DEA. No details. Quesada watches Cohle’s reaction, twists his KofC ring. C becomes indignant--
You realize what we just caught out there?
Rust. It’s a few minutes. Cohle twitches at Quesada’s statement, as though the man’ never used his first name before--
Few minutes won’t make a difference... How’s it working out for you here, detective? In CID?  23. Cohle shrugs, doesn’t answer. Eye-locked to Salter--
Rust. Do something. See if you can guess why the ASA wanted to meet you. Why are we talking? Cohle looks between the two men, studying their expressio

In general I’m not trusted, because I moved in under the aegis of former Superintendent Willey, and at the behest of the DEA. Maybe you got word about Northshore. I don’t know. Half the guys think I haven't earned the shield- which is bullshit, by the way. Check my record with robbery. A beat, as the two bosses are impressed by the precision his analysis. Rust seems vaguely angered-- COHLE (CONT’D) Beyond that, the department’s concerned that I may have been inserted as part of an outside investigation. Into what, who knows? But given that the ASA is here, State Attorney Laughlin could be worried about something. So, if Willey’s out, and at three months I’m still here, it’s time to ask your questions.
See there, Len? I told you.
Alright, then, detective. Given your considerable ability to ascertain a situation, let’s be frank. Why are you here?
I want to work murders. That’s it. I had to get out of Louisiana. Special Agent Willis Bokum owed me a favor. More than one. I asked for something like this. This is what he offered.  24.
Arkansas State Police, though? Just like that?
I passed my forensics lab. Aced Practical Homicide Investigation.
.--Is this convincing, Ken?

Convincing for what? Is the idea that I’m secretly running a DEA op? Quesada and Salter look between one another, then back to Cohle. COHLE (CONT’D) For fuck’s-- I have no connections with any outside agency. My transfer was a favor owed. That’s it. They continue to study him, silent, and Cohle realizes th other question they’ve been sitting on- COHLE (CONT’D) SA Laughlin’s running for governor, rumor has it.
